head.title: Viacom Registers Strong Results Despite a 61% Plunge in Profit

hedline.hl1: Viacom Registers Strong Results Despite a 61% Plunge in Profit

block.p: Viacom Inc. reported a strong performance yesterday for its first quarter, helped in large part by an alliance with the Kirch Group of Germany.
While earnings fell 61 percent, they and the operating cash for the quarter were much better than many analysts had expected.
Viacom Inc. reported a strong performance yesterday for its first quarter, helped in large part by an alliance with the Kirch Group of Germany.
While earnings fell 61 percent, they and the operating cash for the quarter were much better than many analysts had expected.

Viacom, the parent of Paramount Pictures and Blockbuster Video, earned $27.8 million, or 3 cents a share, down from $71.2 million, or 15 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.8 percent, to $2.8 billion from $2.7 billion.
Wall Street had forecast a loss of 3 cents a share, based on the average estimate of 12 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.

Underlying the earnings surprise was the company's cash flow, which was higher than expected. Operating cash flow -- earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- is often considered a better measure of a media company's performance. Cash flow is especially important to a company like Viacom, which is still carrying substantial debt from a number of large acquisitions.

Cash flow for the quarter was $494 million, down from $516 million a year earlier, but the 1995 quarter included a gain of $88 million from an accounting change, Jessica Reif, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company, said in a report.

Viacom said almost one-fifth of its cash flow, or $100 million, stemmed from a five-year agreement signed last month to provide television and film programs to the Kirch Group. The agreement, which was retroactive to the beginning of the year, is valued at $1.7 billion over 10 years, analysts said.

Paramount Pictures and the entertainment group had cash flow of $163.4 million, far more than the $125 million that analysts expected after the poor performance of "Sabrina," starring Harrison Ford, and other films. Cash flow was bolstered by the strong box-office results of "Eye for An Eye," starring Sally Fields, among other films, the company said. The company said selling the video rights to Mel Gibson's "Braveheart" also helped results.
A year earlier, cash flow of $189.8 million included a $68 million gain from an accounting change and the results from "Forrest Gump," starring Tom Hanks.
Viacom's Spelling Entertainment television production company, which has been put up for sale, had a loss of $3 million, compared with profits of $38 million a year earlier.

Cash flow at the networks and broadcasting segment rose 18 percent, to $148.3 million from $125.6 million, because of strong revenue from the company's cable television channels. Viacom's cable networks -- including MTV, Nickelodeon and Showtime -- reported a 20 percent increase in cash flow to $94 million.
